awd_titl_txt: Biophotonic devices for sample-to-answer biomarker analysis
awd_abstract_narration:
This proposal will devise an optofluidic versatile system that will allow pre-analysis manipulation of the sample for removing components that might interfere with the analysis. Using nucleic acids of the target analyte along and with antibodies to detect the presence of a variety of infection-causing viruses in the presence other viruses. The device will be engineered on chips with little a-priori information on the content of the target sample. This is the sample-to-answer system where the developed chip would be available for a variety of yet underdetermined diagnostic tasks. This goal is a quantum leap from the current target-dedicated diagnostics on a chip to the all-purpose diagnostic chip with as broad an application as possible without sacrificing capabilities of sensitivity, selectivity, ease of use and cost. 

The specific objectives are to develop a multi-wavelength waveguide that will provide a multi-source for excitation of biomarkers. A second objective is to develop a sample preparation section on the chip. The final effort in this work will demonstrate the high sensitivity and selectivity of the approach by detecting the Zika virus using both, nucleic acid and biomarkers for the virus in the presence other viruses. The present proposal evolves from a long standing collaboration between the present PI, a physicist in Electrical Engineering at UC Santa Cruz, and a the Hawkins group at BYU. The previous achievements of the collaboration are detailed in the proposal and has enjoyed broad recognition within the community and beyond.

por.por_cntn:
The central goal of this project was the development a novel all-in-one optofluidic platform for sample-to-answer diagnosis and to demonstrate its capabilities with on-chip detection of Zika virus biomarkers. The overall approach was based on the use of polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) chips for both sample preparation and optical analysis. A first major outcome was the development of a reconfigurable optical light source on a chip. A new distributed feedback dye laser with a sidewall grating cavity was demonstrated. The laser could also be dynamically reconfigured by mechanical compression of the grating, allowing to turn the light emission on and off by mechanical force. A second outcome is the successful integration of this new laser source with both a microvalve based sample preparation section and an optical fluorescence analysis section on the same chip. This all-in-one molecular analysis device was then validated with bead-based detection of Zika virus nucleic acid biomarkers. Another outcome of the project was the introduction of new approaches to improving the quality and recognition of weak optical signals generated by single molecules. These improvements are major steps towards development of cost-effective, yet ultrasensitive point-of-case instruments. Specifically, the improvement of signal strength via hydrodynamic focusing of the target particles in the optical excitation spot and the rapid and accurate recognition of single molecule events with a novel signal processing algorithm were demonstrated.

The project also had significant broader impact. A number of undergraduates, graduate students and postdocs were trained with a unique skill set that combines traditional optoelectronic devices, microfabrication, microfluidic device design and biological assay development. In addition, the results form this work were annually disseminated to high school students through the UCSC COSMOS summer program. Finally, a new program for introducing 5th grade elementary school students to nanoscience was designed and implemented, culminating in a visit of 104 students from a local elementary school to get a hands-on introduction to electron microscopy and its applications.
